/home/hammer/slime/src/runtime/totalorder.h

00001 /* Matthew Hammer */
00002 /* <hammer@tti-c.org */
00003 /*                         
00004 
00005  Total order data-structure : from "Two Simplified Algorithms for
00006    Maintaining Order in a List", Bender et. al -- Specifically, this
00007    is the "O(1) worst-case order data structure" from that paper,
00008    which does relabeling based on the "Tag-range relabeling algorithm"
00009    with an extra level of indirection to reduce O(log n) INSERT-time
00010    to O(1).
00011   
00012  API Overview:
00013 
00014    - CREATE() -> x
00015      create a new totalordering with one element, x
00016    
00017    - INSERT(x) -> y
00018      create an immediate successor y to x, return y
00019 
00020    - COMPARE(x, y) -> c,   c in {-1, 0, +1}
00021      follows same conventions as strcmp(3):
00022      (c is -1 if x < y, c is 0 if x = y, c is +1 if x > y)
00023      
00024    - ITERATE(x_1, x_k, f, a_0) -> ()
00025      say [x_1, x_k] = x_1, x_2, ..., x_k
00026      then for each i in {1, ..., k}
00027       let a_i = f(a_(i-1), data(x_i), x_i)
00028      finally, return a_k
00029      
00030      In other words, apply f to each x_i successively, carrying
00031      through an accumulator, initially a_0, which is finally given as
00032      the result.
00033 
00034    - REMOVE(x_1, x_k) -> ()
00035      Say I = [x_1, x_k] = x_1, x_2, ..., x_(k-1), x_k
00036      Let J = (x_1, x_k) = x_2, ..., x_(k-1)
00037      Then removes each x_i in J,
00038      leaving I = x_1, x_k (with no elements between x_1, x_k)
00039 
00040    - NEXT(x) -> y
00041      If x has an immediate successor, y, return y
00042      otherwise, x is the last element, return NULL
00043    
00044    Note on NULL elements:
00045      Although NEXT(x) may return NULL,     
00046      We assume that all API operations that expect an element x are
00047      given such an element and never given NULL.
00048      
00049  Implementation Overview:
00050    
00051    - 1st-level doubly linked list -- uses tag-range relabeling alg.
00052    
00053    - 2nd-level singly linked lists -- as children of each 1st-level
00054      node, these lists are constrained to contain at most (u / log u)
00055      nodes, where u is the number of total tags (u = 2^c for some
00056      constant c, -- e.g, c = 32 or 64, etc).
00057      
00058    When we insert, if we need more room in the tag space -- if there
00059    are no tags available where we'd like to insert -- we rebalance the
00060    2nd-level lists and, if necessary, overflow these lists into new
00061    1st-level nodes -- the new 1st level nodes are added similarly,
00062    where room for new nodes (in tag-space) is made by relabeling the
00063    1st-level list according to the algorithm mentioned above
00064    (tag-range relabeling).  This algoritm relabels the "smallest
00065    enclosing range not in overflow".  To find this range we find the
00066    tag-range density (the number of nodes in an interval of the
00067    ordering versus the number of tags in that interval) and compare
00068    this fraction to T^(-i) for ranges with 2^i tags. (T is picked
00069    between 1.0 and 2.0 and allows the "user" to tune the relabeling
00070    policy).  If the density is higher than T^(-i) we consider
00071    relabeling 2^(i+1) tags next.  This continues until we find a range
00072    not in overflow.
00073 */
00074 
00075 #ifndef __TOTALORDER_H__
00076 #define __TOTALORDER_H__
00077 
00078 #include <inttypes.h>
00079 
00080 typedef struct to_node_s to_node_t;
00081 
00082 /* -- Main API: create, insert, iterate, remove, compare */
00083 
00084 to_node_t* totalorder_create(uintptr_t data);
00085 to_node_t* totalorder_insert(to_node_t* n, uintptr_t data);
00086 void totalorder_iterate(to_node_t* n1, to_node_t* n2);
00087 void totalorder_remove(to_node_t* n1, to_node_t* n2);
00088 void totalorder_remove_succ(to_node_t* n);
00089 int  totalorder_compare(to_node_t* n1, to_node_t* n2);
00090 
00091 /* -- Aux API: next, setdata, getdata */
00092 
00093 to_node_t* totalorder_next(to_node_t* n);
00094 void       totalorder_setdata(to_node_t* n, uintptr_t data);
00095 uintptr_t  totalorder_getdata(to_node_t* n);
00096 
00097 
00098 #endif
